user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calc_userhash:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
calc_userhash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
               const char *username, const size_t username_len,
               const char *realm, const size_t realm_len,
               uint8_t *digest_bin)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL != username);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  digest_update (da, username, username_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update (da, realm, realm_len);
  digest_calc_hash (da, digest_bin);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
digest_calc_hash (da, digest_bin);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment itself does not call any <string.h> functions, so this call alone does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. A violation would occur if the implementation of digest_calc_hash internally uses string functions (e.g. memcpy/memmove/strcpy) to copy the computed hash into digest_bin without ensuring that digest_bin points to an object at least as large as the hash length (for example copying da->hash_len bytes into a smaller buffer). To avoid a violation, either digest_calc_hash must accept/verify a buffer size or the caller must guarantee digest_bin has sufficient space for the hash.
